item.label: Cerebrum
item.name: Cerebrum
item.description: The cerebrum consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres.  Each cerebral hemisphere consists of lobes:  frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal.  In some instances a limbic lobe is designated-- consisting of a portion of the medial aspect of the other lobes.

item.label: Frontal lobes
item.name: Frontal lobe
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Orbital gyri
item.name: Orbital gyri
item.description: Orbital gyri are located on the ventral surface of the frontal lobe.  In this location, they are positioned above the orbits of the skull.

item.label: Gyrus rectus
item.name: Gyrus rectus
item.description: The gyrus rectus is a slender, straight gyrus on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe.  It is located just medial to the position of the olfactory bulb and olfactory tract. It is involved in limbic system circuits.

item.label: Temporal lobes
item.name: Temporal lobe
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Parahippocampal gyrus
item.name: Parahippolcampal gyrus
item.description: The parahippocampal gyrus is the most medial gyrus on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe. The hippocampus is cortex that is rolled up inside the parahippocampal gyrus. The rostral portion of this gyrus is the entorhinal cortex.

item.label: Uncus
item.name: Uncus
item.description: The uncus is a bulge on the anterior aspect of the parahippocampal gyrus caused by the underlying amygdala. it can herniate through the tentorial notch in the event of increased intracranial pressure due to a supratentorial space-occupying lesion.

item.label: Olfactory tract
item.name: Olfactory tract
item.description: Located on the ventral surface of the orbital gyri of the frontal lobe, the olfactory tract consists of the axons of the olfactory bulb neurons. These axons branch into the medial and lateral olfactory stria forming the olfactory trigone; they will terminate in the olfactory (piriform) cerebral cortex as well as the amygdala.

item.label: Olfactory trigone
item.name: Olfactory trigone
item.description: The olfactory trigone is a small triangular area in front of the anterior perforated substance on the inferior aspect of the brain.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Infundibulum
item.name: Infundibulum
item.description: The infundibulum is the hollow, funnel-like stalk of the pituitary gland or hypophysis. It extends from the medial eminence of the hypothalamus to the posterior lobe of the pituitary. Embryologicaly, it and the posterior pituitary are derived from a ventral outgrowth of the diencephalon.

item.label: Median eminence
item.name: Median eminence
item.description: The median eminence is a surface elevation in the mid-portion of the tuber cinereum of the hypothalamus. It is located between the optic chiasm and mammillary bodies on the ventral aspect of the hypothalamus. The infundibulum or stalk of the pituitary extends from the midpoint of this area to the posterior lobe of the pituitary.  The medial eminence is one of the circumventricular organs and is the site of release of hypothalamic hormones into the hypothalamic-hypophyseal portal system.

item.label: Tuber cinereum
item.name: Tuber cinereum
item.description: The tuber cinereum is a region of the hypothalamic gray matter that includes the median eminence and the base of the infundibular stalk. It is bounded by the optic chiasm, optic tracts and the anterior edge of the mammillary bodies. Important in the hypothalamic regulation of the adenohypophysis.

item.label: Mammillary bodies
item.name: Mammillary body
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic nerves
item.name: Optic nerve
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic chiasm
item.name: Optic chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic tracts
item.name: Optic tract
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Cranial Nerves of Midbrain
item.name: Nerves of midbrain
item.description: The cranial nerves associated with the midbrain are the oculomotor (III) and trochear (IV).

item.label: Oculomotor nerve
item.name: Oculomotor nerve
item.description: The third or oculomotor cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the ipsilateral medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palapebrae muscles that move the eye. It also includes parasympathetic fibers that terminate in the ipsilateral ciliary ganglion; post-ganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion innervate the constrictors of the pupil and the ciliary muscles.

item.label: Trochlear nerve
item.name: Trochlear nerve
item.description: The fourth or trochlear cranial nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the contralateral eye. It is the only cranial nerve to exit the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. This location is just caudal to the inferior colliculi of the midbrain.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Cranial Nerves of Pons
item.name: Nerves of pons
item.description: The cranial nerves associated with the pons are the trigeminal (V), abducens (VI), facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII).  Note that the vestibular and cochlear nuclei are actually located in both the pons and medulla beneath the vestibular area --as seen in the floor of the fourth ventricle.  The vestibular and cochlear nerves enter the brainstem at the junction of the pons with the medulla in the cerebellopontine angle.

item.label: Trigeminal nerve
item.name: Trigeminal nerve
item.description: The fifth or trigeminal cranial nerve enters/exits the brain stem through the basilar portion of the pons. It provides somatosensory innervation to the head via its ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular roots which converge upon the trigeminal ganglion and then form a massive sensory root entering the brainstem. It provides motor innervation to the muscles derived from the first branchial arch (muscles of mastication, tensor tympani, anterior belly of diagastric, tensor veli palatini and mylohyoid) via a smaller motor root that distributes with the mandibular sensory root.

item.label: Abducens nerve
item.name: Abducens nerve
item.description: The abducens nerve is the sixth cranial nerve.  It innervates the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle. It exits the brain stem anteriorly at the pontomedullary junction.

item.label: Facial nerve
item.name: Facial nerve
item.description: The facial or seventh cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem in the cerebellopontine angle with the vestibulocochlear nerve. The most important sensory component carries taste from the anterior 2/3rds of the tongue; motor components innervate the skeletal muscles of facial expression, stapedius, etc. as well as provide the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands.

item.label: Vestibulocochlear nerve
item.name: Vestibulocochlear nerve
item.description: The vestibulocochlear nerve is AKA the statoacoustic nerve. This eighth cranial nerve enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. It carries information from the hair cell receptors in the organ of Corti of the cochlear duct as well as from the vestibular organs (cristae of the semicircular ducts and maculae of the utricle and saccule of the inner ear).

item.label: Medulla
item.name: Medulla
item.description: The medulla is AKA the medulla oblongata. The most caudal aspect of the brain stem, it is located between the pons and spinal cord. It contains structures vital to survival such as cardiovascular and respiratory centers, as well as many cranial nerve nuclei. The major ascending and descending tracts travel through it between the spinal cord and higher centers. It originates developmentally from the myelencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Pyramid
item.name: Pyramid
item.description: The pyramid is a large fiber bundle located on the medial and ventral aspect of the medulla. It consists of corticospinal (and some corticobulbar) fibers that originate in the ipsilateral cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus and elsewhere). These upper motor neuron fibers terminate on lower motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord (corticospinal) and on cranial nerve motor neurons in the medulla (corticobulbar). Often referred to as the pyramidal tract.

item.label: Pyramidal decussation
item.name: Pyramidal decussation
item.description: The pyramidal decussation is where the corticospinal tract fibers that travel through the pyramid of the medulla, cross or decussate the midline of the neuraxis. This decussation marks the boundary between the medulla and spinal cord. As this tract travels in the spinal cord, it is known as the lateral corticospinal tract. Note that a few corticospinal fibers do not cross in this decussation and thus remain in a vental location in the spinal cord where they are known as the ventral corticospinal tract; these ventral corticospinal fibers generally descend only to cervical segments and will decussate in the ventral white commissure of the spinal cord before they synapse in the ventral horn.

item.label: Olive
item.name: Olive
item.description: The olive is an oval-shaped bulge on the ventral lateral aspect of the medulla. The inferior olivary nucleus is located inside of this elevated area.

item.label: Cranial Nerves of Medulla
item.name: Nerves of medulla
item.description: The cranial nerves associated with the medulla are the glossopharygeal (IX), vagus (X) and hypoglossal (XII).  Note that the vestibular and cochlear nuclei (VIII) are located in both the pons and medulla; as such they can be considered as part of the medulla as well.  The accessory nerve (XI) originates in the cervical spinal cord.

item.label: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.name: Glossopharyngeal nerve
item.description: The ninth or glossopharyngeal cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive. The sensory component includes tactile sensation and taste from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue as well as input from the carotid body/sinus, middle and external ear; the motor component innervates the stylopharyngeus muscle (3rd pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that control secretion of the parotid gland.

item.label: Vagus nerve
item.name: Vagus nerve
item.description: The tenth or vagus cranial nerve has both sensory and motor components which enter/exit the brain stem as a series of rootlets along the lateral aspect of the medulla dorsal to the olive and just caudal to the glossopharyngeal nerve. The most significant sensory component includes general sensation from the viscera, including input from the aortic body/sinus; the motor component innervates the laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles (4th and 6th pharyngeal arch origin) and provides the parasympathetic preganglionic fibers that innervate the thoracic and abdominal viscera.

item.label: Hypoglossal nerve
item.name: Hypoglossal nerve
item.description: The twelfth or hypoglossal cranial nerve is purely motor and innervates the ipsilateral intrinsic and extrinsic skeletal muscles of the tongue (except for the palatoglossus). It exits the medulla as a series of rootlets in the ventral lateral or anterolateral fissure between the olive and the pyramid in the medulla.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Flocculus
item.name: Flocculus
item.description: The flocculus is the hemispheric portion of the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum.  It is concerned with balance and equilibrium as well as movements of the eyes.

item.label: Tonsil
item.name: Tonsil
item.description: The tonsils of the cerebellum are the medial, inferior part of the posterior lobe of each cerebellar hemisphere, adjacent to the medulla and near the foramen magnum. The tonsils are of clinical significance since they may herniate through the foramen magnum with increased intracranial pressure.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Cerebellar peduncle (middle)
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Posterolateral fissure
item.name: Posterolateral fissure
item.description: The posterolateral fissure of the cerebellum separates the posterior lobe from the flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum. It extends into both the vermal and hemispheric aspects of the cerebellum.

item.label: Spinal cord
item.name: Spinal cord
item.description: The spinal cord is that portion of the central nervous system that extends from the medulla to the conus medullaris. It consists of 31 segments (8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, 1 coccygeal) and has enlargements at the levels serving the limbs (C5 - T1 and L2 - S3).
